statement.tex: \text{Is the function }f(x) = e^{2x}\text{ strictly increasing,}\\ \text{decreasing or constant in }\mathbb{R}?

step.reason: \text{For a function to be strictly increasing, }f(x)\\ \text{must increase as x increases and vice-versa}

step.tex: \begin{align} \frac{d}{dx}e^{2x}&= e^{2x}\cdot\frac{d}{dx}2x \\ &= 2\cdot e^{2x}\\ \gt 0\text{ when }x&\gt 0\text{ and }\lt 0\text{ when }x\lt 0 \end{align} \\ \text{Hence, }e^{2x}\text{ is neither strictly increasing}\\ \text{nor strictly decreasing in }\mathbb{R}.
step.reason: e^{2x}\text{ can never be }\lt 0.\text{It can be a very small}\\ \text{number. But always }\gt 0.
